page.title: 05HOARWITHY BRIDGE
page.content: For many centuries there has been a crossing over the river Wye at Hoarwithy connecting King's Caple with the main routes into ROSS AND HEREFORD.Early Travellers used the ford of ferry crossing,which were replaced by a timber bridge in 1856.The resent iron structutre was erected in 1876 and consists of a narrow road bridge with a weight limit of 7tons,unsuitable for the heavy machinery and vehicles of the 1980s.In1935 the Herefordshire County Council purchased the bridge and freed it of tolls,since then they have maintained the bridge,which is now in a deterioratingstate.The inhabitants of K.C.are reliant upon the bridge,andfeel it should be replaced with a stronger structure.The County Council'see no possibility in the near future of the bridge being replaced.
